snippet: The schools worry about what would happen under a city run by Bill de Blasio, a harsh critic who wants to start charging them rent for using city space.
abstract: Many New York City charter school leaders are concerned that the support they have enjoyed during three terms of Mayor Michael R Bloomberg may be in peril; leading candidate to succeed Bloomberg, Democrat Bill de Blasio, is a critic of charter schools and Bloomberg's educational agenda who has said he would stop offering many of the city's 183 charter schools free rent; by contrast, Republican candidate Joseph J Lhota is a fierce defender of charter schools.

byline.contributor: Al Baker and Kyle Spencer contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: The schools worry about what would happen under a city run by Bill de Blasio, a harsh critic who wants to start charging them rent for using city space.

headline.main: City’s Charter Schools Fear Having de Blasio for a Landlord
headline.print_headline: City’s Charter Schools Fear Having de Blasio for a Landlord
